    Structure, Hydrogen Storage, and Luminescence Properties of Three 3D Metal−Organic Frameworks with NbO and PtS Topologies

    • Ming Xue
      • , 
    • Guangshan Zhu*
      • , 
    • Yangxue Li

    Abstract

    Three 3D multifunctional microporous metal−organic frameworks (MOFs), Cu2(ABTC)(H2O)2·(DMF)2(H2O) (JUC-62), Cd2(ABTC)(DMF)3·(DMF)2 (JUC-63), and Mn(H2ABTC)(DMF)2 (JUC-64) (H4ABTC = 3,3′,5,5′-azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid, DMF = N,N′-dimethylformamide, and JUC = Jilin University China) have been synthesized by self-assembly of a rigid tetra-carboxylate ligand H4ABTC and corresponding transition metal salts under mild conditions. X-ray crystallography reveals that their topologies are based on NbO (JUC-62) and PtS (JUC-63 and JUC-64) nets, constructed of 4-connected rectangular ABTC4− units with 4-connected square paddle-wheel Cu2(CO2)4(H2O)2 secondary building units (SBUs), tetrahedral bimetallic Cd2(CO2)4(DMF)3 SBUs, and tetrahedral monometallic Mn(CO2)4(DMF)3 SBUs, respectively. High-pressure hydrogen sorption of the activated JUC-62 reveals a type I profile at 77 K, which is saturated at 40 bar with a hydrogen uptake of about 4.71 wt%. Photoluminescence investigations reveal that JUC-62 and JUC-63 display strong main emission spectra peaks at 392 and 402 nm, respectively.

    Synopsis

    Three 3D multifunctional microporous MOFs, Cu2(ABTC)(H2O)2·(DMF)2(H2O) (JUC-62), Cd2(ABTC)(DMF)3·(DMF)2 (JUC-63), and Mn(H2ABTC)(DMF)2 (JUC-64) were synthesized with NbO (JUC-62) and PtS (JUC-63 and JUC-64) nets, respectively. High-pressure hydrogen sorption of the activated JUC-62 reveals a type I profile at 77 K, which is saturated at 40 bar with a hydrogen uptake of about 4.71 wt%.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References
    Metal−organic framework (MOF) design and construction is currently a flourishing field of research owing to the intriguing molecular topologies and the potentially exploitable adsorption, catalytic, fluorescence, and magnetic properties.(1) The recent discovery that MOFs take up significant amounts of hydrogen has spurred interest in these materials as possible storage media for hydrogen fuel cell vehicles.(2) Meanwhile an important aspect of this relatively new chemistry is the analysis and direction of network topologies of the MOFs, which is a precondition to make true and significant development.(3) In particular, exploring highly symmetrical multifunctional organic ligands and suitable metal salts in a design strategy to construct coordination complexes with special topologies is of higher interest, due to the predictability of the resulting networks.(4) Some structures of minerals, such as quartz diamond, rutile, perovsktie, NbO, PtS, and feldspar, have been artificially produced by replacing monatomic anions (O2−, S2−) with polyatomic organic ligands as linkers and utilizing the well-defined coordination geometries of metal centers as nodes.(5) Among an infinite number of possibilities, the three-dimensional (3-D) NbO network was identified as the default using square-planar 4-connected nodes, and PtS networks could be constructed when using both square-planar and tetrahedral 4-connected nodes.(6)
    Recently, we designed a tetra-carboxylate ligand, 3,3′,5,5′-azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid (H4ABTC),(7) which can act as a rigid rectangular-planar 4-connected ligand. We expect to prepare some microporous MOFs with 4-connected topologies from different coordination geometric transition metal ions with this ligand. During the course of our work, three metal-organic frameworks were reported on this ligand.(8) Herein, we will describe three compounds Cu2(ABTC)(H2O)2·(DMF)2(H2O) (JUC-62), Cd2(ABTC)(DMF)3·(DMF)2 (JUC-63), and Mn(H2ABTC)(DMF)2 (JUC-64) (H4ABTC = 3,3′,5,5′-azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid, DMF = N,N′-dimethylformamide, and JUC = Jilin University China), possessing NbO and PtS net topologies, respectively, from Cu2+, Cd2+, or Mn2+ ions with the H4ABTC ligand. Of further interest, the high-pressure hydrogen storage and fluorescence properties have been examined.

    Experimental Section

    Materials and Measurements

    All reagents and solvents were used as received from commercial suppliers without further purification. Fluorescence spectroscopy data were recorded on a LS55 luminescence spectrometer. Analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed under oxygen atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C/min using a Perkin-Elmer TGA 7 thermogravimetric analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a Siemens D5005 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å).

    Synthesis of Cu2(ABTC)(H2O)2·(DMF)2(H2O) (JUC-62)

    A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·(H2O)2.5 (24 mg, 0.1 mmol) and H4ABTC (18 mg, 0.05 mmol) was dissolved in DMF/ethanol/H2O (5:3:1) at room temperature in a 25 mL beaker. Sufficient 2 M HNO3 was added until the mixture became clear. The mixture was left undisturbed at 60 °C for 2 days to give blue-green, polyhedral crystals. Yield: 61% (based on H4ABTC). Elemental anal. Calcd C22H26N4O13Cu2 (680): C, 38.82; H, 3.85; N, 8.24. Found: C, 38.91; H, 3.78; N, 8.32.

    Synthesis of Cd2(ABTC)(DMF)3·(DMF)2 (JUC-63)

    A mixture of Cd(NO3)2·(H2O)4 (30 mg, 0.1 mmol) and H4ABTC (11 mg, 0.03 mmol) was dissolved in DMF/ethanol/H2O (12:3:1) at room temperature in a 25 mL beaker. Sufficient 2 M HNO3 was added until the mixture became clear. The mixture was left undisturbed at room temperature for 1 week to give yellowy, block-shaped crystals. Yield: 56% (based on H4ABTC). Elemental anal. Calcd C31H27N7O13Cd2 (932.97): C, 39.87; H, 2.92; N, 10.51. Found: C, 39.72; H, 2.81; N, 10.68.

    Synthesis of Mn(H2ABTC)(DMF)2 (JUC-64)

    A mixture of MnCl2·(H2O)4 (40 mg, 0.2 mmol) and H4ABTC (11 mg, 0.03 mmol) was dissolved in DMF/glycol/H2O (8:2:1) at room temperature in a 25 mL beaker. Sufficient 2 M HCl was added until the mixture became clear. The mixture was left undisturbed at 55 °C for 2 days to give orange, block-shaped crystals. Yield: 73% (based on H4ABTC). Elemental anal. Calcd C22H22N4O10Mn (557.07): C, 47.39; H, 3.98; N, 10.05. Found: C, 47.26; H, 3.82; N, 10.16.

    X-ray Crystallographic Study

    Diffraction intensities for JUC-62, JUC-63, and JUC-64 were collected on a computer-controlled Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at room temperature by using the ω-scan technique. Raw data for all structures were processed using SAINT and absorption corrections were applied using SADABS.(9) The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the program SHELXTL.(10) Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were set in calculated positions. For JUC-62, guest solvent molecules were highly disordered and were impossible to refine using conventional discrete-atom models. To resolve these issues, the contribution of solvent electron density was removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON.(11) Pertinent crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters were summarized in Table 1, and the selected bond lengths and bond angles of JUC-62, JUC-63, and JUC-64 are listed in Table 2 and Tables S1−S3 in Supporting Information, respectively. Crystal drawings were produced by Cerius2 soft. CCDC-666395 (JUC-62), CCDC-666396 (JUC-63), and CCDC-666397 (JUC-64) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html (or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB21EZ, U.K.; fax: (44) 1223-336-003; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

    High-Pressure Hydrogen Sorption Measurement

    High-pressure hydrogen sorption isotherm measurements on JUC-62 were recorded using a RUBOTHERM magnetic suspension balance (Ankersmid B.V., Netherlands). High purity hydrogen (99.999%) was used for the measurement. About 150 mg of as-synthesized blue-green crystalline sample of JUC-62 was immersed in acetone for 2 h, and fresh acetone was added after the extract was decanted, which was operated at least five times. Then the crystals were allowed to immerse in acetone for 24 h to remove the guest solvates (DMF and H2O). After the removal of acetone by decanting, the sample was dried under a dynamic vacuum (<10−3 Torr) at room temperature overnight. Before the measurement, the sample was activated under 10−5 Torr at 120 °C for 24 h on the apparatus resulting in purple crystalline material, which can remove the terminal water molecules bound with Cu(II) ions to introduce open metal sites.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References
    Solvothermal reactions of Cu(NO3)2·(H2O)2.5, Cd(NO3)2·(H2O)4, or MnCl2·(H2O)4 with H4ABTC organic linker in a slightly acidified mixture DMF/EtOH/H2O or DMF/glycol/H2O readily led to highly crystalline Cu2(ABTC)(H2O)2·(DMF)2(H2O) (JUC-62), Cd2(ABTC)(DMF)3·(DMF)2 (JUC-63), and Mn(H2ABTC)(DMF)2 (JUC-64), respectively, in high yield. Addition of a small amount of dilute nitric/muriatic acid favors the formation of larger crystals for structure characterization. As expected, Cu2(CO2)4(H2O)2 paddle-wheel secondary building units were formed in situ during the reaction, leading to NbO net (JUC-62) with rectangular 4-connected H4ABTC. As both Cd2+ and Mn2+ ions are six coordinated in which the resulting secondary building units act as tetrahedral nodes, compounds JUC-63 and JUC-64 have PtS topology.
    X-ray crystallography for JUC-62 reveals that each Cu(II) ion is coordinated by five O atoms in pyramidal geometry. A pair of copper-centered pentahedra are bridged by four different carboxylate groups of four independent H4ABTC organic linkers, forming the well-known Cu2(CO2)4(H2O)2 paddle-wheel units, the Cu···Cu distance is 2.665(1) Å. One H2O molecule binds to each Cu(II) center along the paddle-wheel axis. So the Cu2(CO2)4(H2O)2 unit is a 4-connected square secondary building unit (SBU) that is defined by the carboxylate carbon atoms (Figure 1a). While each ABTC4− unit coordinates to four pairs of Cu(II) ions can act as a 4-connected rectangular SBU, which is defined by the 3,3′,5, and 5′ carbon atoms (Figure 1b). Extension of the coordination geometry around each square SBU and rectangular SBU will therefore give a 3D porous framework with NbO-type topology (Figure 1d). The smaller cage is defined by six paddle-wheel Cu2(CO2)4(H2O)2 inorganic SBUs with a pore diameter of about 9 Å, and the larger rhombic cage is defined by six ABTC4− organic SBUs with a pore diameter of about 11 Å (Figure S1, Supporting Information). There are hexagonal channels with a pore diameter of approximately 9.6 Å viewed along the c axis (Figures 1c and S2a, Supporting Information). These channels are interconnected through the triangular windows, which can be seen along the a axis (Figure S2b, Supporting Information). The void space is filled with two coordinated H2O molecules, one H2O and two DMF guest molecules, as established by elemental analysis and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA).(12) The effective free volume of JUC-62 is calculated by PLATON analysis as being 65.9% (0.783 cm3 g−1) of the crystal volume without DMF and H2O guest molecules. When removing the terminal H2O molecules, the effective free volume reaches 70.1% (0.888 cm3 g−1) of the crystal volume.
    X-ray crystallography reveals that JUC-63 is also 3D 4-connected network constructed from Cd2(CO2)4(DMF)3 units and ABTC4− units. As shown in Figure 2a, both Cd(II) ions adopt distorted octahedral coordination geometries with six oxygen atoms and are bridged through three carboxylate groups: two bidentate and one chelating/bridging tridentate. One Cd(II) center has three terminal DMF molecules while the other has one chelating bidentate carboxylates. When the point-of-extension is considered by the carboxylate carbon atoms, this unit is a 4-connected distorted tetrahedral SBU and each ABTC4− unit is surrounded with four pairs of Cd(II) ions that can act as a 4-connected rectangular SBU (Figure 2b). Extension of the coordination geometry around each tetrahedral SBU and rectangular SBU will give a 3D porous framework with PtS-type topology (Figure 2d). There are open rectangular channels of approximately 6.3 × 10 Å2 along the [011] direction and rhombic channels of 8.3 × 9.6 Å2 along the [100] directions, respectively (Figures 2c and S3, Supporting Information). The channels are filled with three coordinated DMF molecules and two DMF guest molecules, as established by elemental analysis and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA).(13)
    X-ray crystallography reveals that JUC-64 is also 3D PtS network constructed from Mn(CO2)4(DMF)3 units and H2ABTC2− units, in which each Mn(II) center is distorted octahedral geometry with four unidentate carboxylates of four separate H4ABTC ligands and two coordinated DMF molecules. When the point-of-extension is considered, this unit approximates a tetrahedron SBU (Figure 3a). While each H2ABTC2− unit coordinates to four Mn(II) ions can act as a 4-connected rectangular SBU (Figure 3b), which connected with tetrahedral SBU generating a 3D porous framework with PtS-type topology (Figure 3d). There are open rectangular channels of approximately 4.6 × 7.3 Å2 along the c axis (Figures 3c). The void space is filled with two coordinated DMF molecules, as established by elemental analysis and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA).(14)

    High-Pressure Hydrogen Sorption

    The JUC-62 sample was fully activated by the procedure described above in the Experimental Section. The integrity of the framework was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (Figure S4, Supporting Information). The high-pressure hydrogen storage capability of the activated JUC-62 was evaluated at 77 K. As shown in Figure 4, the hydrogen adsorption isotherm of the activated JUC-62 reveals a type I profile which is saturated at 40 bar with a hydrogen uptake of about 4.71 wt%, which corresponds to a H2 storage capacity of 523.4 mL g−1 (Table 3). The value is slightly higher than that of MOF-505 but inferior to those of the two other MOFs using isophthalate derivatives.(6h) Although the hydrogen uptake of JUC-62 is lower than some reported MOFs with high hydrogen storage (such as MIL-101, MOF-177, MOF-20, and MOF-5),(15) to the best of our knowledge it is comparable with many MOFs and is higher than “active” carbon (CECA, France) and purified single-walled carbon nanotubes.(16)
    Table 3. Hydrogen Sorption Property of the Activated JUC-62
    calcd density (g/cm3)aaccessible voids (%)apore volume (cm3/g)asaturated H2uptake (wt %)saturated H2uptake (g/L)adsorbed H2density (g/cm3)b

    Photoluminescent Properties

    The solid-state excitation−emission spectroscopy of the free H4ABTC ligand, JUC-62 and JUC-63 have been performed at room temperature (Figure 5). The emission spectrum for free H4ABTC ligand shows a main peak at 378 nm and a weak shoulder band at 423 nm with λex = 310 nm. Compared with pure H4ABTC ligand, the intense emission peak of JUC-62 is found at 392 nm and a weak shoulder band at 426 nm with an excitation band at 253 nm. When excited by 320 nm light, JUC-63 exhibits a main peak at 402 nm and a shoulder band at 440 nm. The emissions of JUC-62 and JUC-63 are very similar to the free ligand transitions and may be chiefly ligand-centered electronic transitions perturbed by the coordination to metal ions rather than to protons. The difference in their emissions is probably due to the differences in metal ions and coordination environment around them, because the photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the metal ions and the ligands coordinated around them.(17) These observations suggest that these compounds could find applications as potential fluorescent porous materials.(18)
    In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized and characterized three 3D porous metal-organic frameworks Cu2(ABTC)(H2O)2·(DMF)2(H2O) (JUC-62) with NbO-type topology, Cd2(ABTC)(DMF)3·(DMF)2 (JUC-63), and Mn(H2ABTC)(DMF)2 (JUC-64) with PtS-type topology, constructed from tetra-carboxylic H4ABTC ligand to Cu2+, Cd2+, or Mn2+ ions, respectively. High-pressure hydrogen sorption of the activated JUC-62 reveals a type I profile at 77 K, which is saturated at 40 bar with a hydrogen uptake of about 4.71 wt%. Photoluminescence investigations reveal that JUC-62 and JUC-63 display strong main emission spectra peaks at 392 and 402 nm, respectively.

      Role of Solvent-Host Interactions That Lead to Very Large Swelling of Hybrid Frameworks
      Serre, C.; Mellot-Draznieks, C.; Surble, S.; Audebrand, N.; Filinchuk, Y.; Ferey, G.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2007), 315 (5820), 1828-1831CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      An unusually large expansion upon solvent adsorption occurs without apparent bond breaking in the network of a series of isoreticular chromium(III) or iron(III) dicarboxylates labeled MIL-88A to D [dicarbox = fumarate (88A); terephthalate (1,4-BDC) (88B); 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate (2,6-NDC) (88C); and 4-4'-biphenyldicarboxylate (4-4'-BPDC) (88D)]. This reversible "breathing" motion was analyzed in terms of cell dimensions (extent of breathing), movements within the framework (mechanism of transformation), and the interactions between the guests and the skeleton. In situ techniques show that these flexible solids are highly selective absorbents and that this selectivity is strongly dependent on the nature of the org. linker.

      Framework Engineering by Anions and Porous Functionalities of Cu(II)/4,4'-bpy Coordination Polymers
      Noro, Shin-ichiro; Kitaura, Ryo; Kondo, Mitsuru; Kitagawa, Susumu; Ishii, Tomohiko; Matsuzaka, Hiroyuki; Yamashita, Masahiro
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2002), 124 (11), 2568-2583CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A combination of framework-builder Cu2+ and 4,4'-bipyridine (4,4'-bpy) ligand) and framework-regulator (AF6 type anions; A = Si, Ge, and P) provides novel porous coordination polymers. The highly porous coordination polymers {[Cu(AF6)(4,4'-bpy)2]·8H2O}n (A = Si (1a·8H2O), Ge (2a·8H2O)) afford robust 3-dimensional (3-D), microporous networks (3-dimensional Regular Grid) by using AF62- anions. The channel size of these complexes is ∼8 × 8 Å2 along the c-axis and 6 × 2 Å2 along the a- or b-axes. When compds. 1a·8H2O or 2a·8H2O were immersed in H2O, a conversion of 3-dimensional networks (1a·8H2O or 2a·8H2O) to interpenetrated networks {[Cu(4,4'-bpy)2(H2O)2]·AF6}n (A = Si (1b) and Ge (2b)) (2-dimensional Interpenetration) took place. This 2-dimensional interpenetrated network 1b shows unique dynamic anion-exchange properties, which accompany drastic structural conversions. When a PF6- monoanion instead of AF62- dianions was used as the framework-regulator with another co-counteranion (coexistent anions), porous coordination polymers with various types of frameworks, {[Cu2(4,4'-bpy)5(H2O)4]·anions·2H2O·4EtOH}n (anions = 4PF6- (3·2H2O·4EtOH), 2PF6- + 2ClO4- (4·2H2O·4EtOH)) (2-dimensional Double-Layer), {[Cu2(PF6)(NO3)(4,4'-bpy)4]·2PF6·2H2O}n (5·2PF6·2H2O) (3-dimensional Undulated Grid), {[Cu(PF6)(4,4'-bpy)2(MeCN)]·PF6·2MeCN}n (6·2MeCN) (2-dimensional Grid), and {[Cu(4,4'-bpy)2(H2O)2]·PF6·BF4}n (7) (2-dimensional Grid), were obtained, where the three modes of PF6- anions are obsd. 5·2PF6·2H2O has rare PF6- bridges. The PF6- and NO3- monoanions alternately link to the Cu(II) centers in the undulated 2-dimensional sheets of [Cu(4,4'-bpy)2]n to form a 3-dimensional porous network. The free PF6- anions are included in the channels. 6·2MeCN affords both free and terminal-bridged PF6- anions. 3·2H2O·4EtOH, 4·2H2O·4EtOH, and 7 bear free PF6- anions. All of the anions in 3·2H2O·4EtOH and 4·2H2O·4EtOH are freely located in the channels constructed from a host network. Interestingly, these Cu(II) frameworks are rationally controlled by counteranions and selectively converted to other frameworks.

      Hysteretic Adsorption and Desorption of Hydrogen by Nanoporous Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Zhao, Xuebo; Xiao, Bo; Fletcher, Ashleigh J.; Thomas, K. Mark; Bradshaw, Darren; Rosseinsky, Matthew J.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2004), 306 (5698), 1012-1015CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      Adsorption and desorption of hydrogen from nanoporous materials, such as activated C, is usually fully reversible. The authors prepd. nanoporous metal-org. framework materials with flexible linkers in which the pore openings, as characterized in the static structures, appear to be too small to allow H2 to pass. The authors observe hysteresis in their adsorption and desorption kinetics above the supercrit. temp. of H2 that reflects the dynamical opening of the windows between pores. This behavior would allow H2 to be adsorbed at high pressures but stored at lower pressures.

      Chiral porous coordination networks: rational design and applications in enantioselective processes
      Kesanli, Banu; Lin, Wenbin
      Coordination Chemistry Reviews (2003), 246 (1-2), 305-326CODEN: CCHRAM; ISSN:0010-8545. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
      A review is presented which provides a short discussion of recent progress in the synthesis and characterization of homochiral metal-org. coordination networks (MOCNs) and their applications in the areas of asym. catalysis and chiral sepns. Although chiral MOCNs can be constructed from achiral components, the resulting bulk solids tend to be racemic and are thus not useful for enantioselective processes. A couple of examples of homochiral solids built from achiral bridging ligands are presented along with more prevalent homochiral MOCNs built from chiral bridging ligands that are categorized based on their network dimensionality. Preliminary applications of these homochiral solids in asym. catalysis and chiral sepns. are also presented.

      A homochiral metal-organic porous material for enantioselective separation and catalysis
      Seo, Jung Soo; Whang, Dongmok; Lee, Hyoyoung; Jun, Sung Im; Oh, Jinho; Jeon, Young Jin; Kim, Kimoon
      Nature (London) (2000), 404 (6781), 982-986CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A homochiral metal-org. porous material with a carboxylic group at one end and a pyridyl group at the other forming oxo-bridged trinuclear metal carboxylate units in a three-dimensional framework was prepd., that allows enantioselective inclusion of metal complexes in its pores and catalyzes transesterification reactions in an enantioselective manner. The enantiopure chiral building block was prepd. from D-tartaric acid and 4-aminopyridine; then reaction with Zn2+ produced a homochiral open-framework solid, D-POST-1. The enantiomorphic L-POST-1 was obtained from the enantiomer of the building block and Zn2+ under the same conditions. The pyridyl groups in POST-1 can be converted to N-methylpyridinium without any changes of the network structure; the anion can be reversibly exchanged with other anions, e.g., PF6-, I3-, p-toluenesulfonate, etc. The pore size of POST-1 materials is modulated by N-alkylation and is dependent on alkyl chain length. The pyridyl groups are responsible for the catalytic activity of the oxo-bridged trinuclear metal complexes, in e.g., transesterification of 2,4-dinitrophenyl acetate (NPA) with ethanol, which produced Et acetate in 77% yield, only in the presence of POST-1. Transesterification with bulkier alcs. occurs more slowly or not at all, suggesting that catalysis occurs mainly in the POST-1 channels. The catalytic activity of D- and L-POST-1 is enantioselective as obsd. in the transesterification of NPA with 1-phenyl-2-propanol, which produces the corresponding esters with about 88% enantiomeric excess in favor of the resp. enantiomer.

      Microporous Metal Organic Materials: Promising Candidates as Sorbents for Hydrogen Storage
      Pan, Long; Sander, Michelle B.; Huang, Xiaoying; Li, Jing; Smith, Milton; Bittner, Edward; Bockrath, Bradley; Johnson, J. Karl
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2004), 126 (5), 1308-1309CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Although extensive efforts have been made to improve H storage techniques, there is no viable storage technol. capable of meeting the DOE cost and performance targets. H adsorption properties are presented.

      Hydrogen Storage in Microporous Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Rosi, Nathaniel L.; Eckert, Juergen; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Vodak, David T.; Kim, Jaheon; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2003), 300 (5622), 1127-1130CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      Metal-org. framework-5 (MOF-5) Zn4O(BDC)3 (BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) with a cubic three-dimensional extended porous structure adsorbed hydrogen up to 4.5 wt.% (17.2 hydrogen mols. per formula unit) at 78 K and 1.0 wt.% at room temp. and pressure of 20 bar. Inelastic neutron scattering spectroscopy of the rotational transitions of the adsorbed hydrogen mols. indicates two well-defined binding sites (termed I and II), which the authors assoc. with hydrogen binding to zinc and the BDC linker, resp. Preliminary studies on topol. similar isoreticular metal-org. framework-6 and -8 (IRMOF-6 and -8) having cyclobutylbenzene and naphthalene linkers, resp., gave approx. double and quadruple (2.0 wt.%) the uptake found for MOF-5 at room temp. and 10 bar.

      Synthesis, X-ray crystal structures, and gas sorption properties of pillared square grid nets based on paddle-wheel motifs: Implications for hydrogen storage in porous materials
      Chun, Hyungphil; Dybtsev, Danil N.; Kim, Hyunuk; Kim, Kimoon
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2005), 11 (12), 3521-3529CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A systematic modulation of org. ligands connecting dinuclear paddle-wheel motifs leads to isomorphous metal-org. porous materials that have a three-dimensional connectivity and interconnected pores. Arom. dicarboxylates such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (1,4-bdc), tetramethylterephthalate (tmbdc), 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate (1,4-ndc), tetrafluoroterephthalate (tfbdc), or 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate (2,6-ndc) are linear linkers that form two-dimensional layers, and diamine ligands, 4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (dabco) or 4,4'-dipyridyl (bpy), coordinate at both sides of Zn2 paddle-wheel units to bridge the layers vertically. The resulting open frameworks [Zn2(1,4-bdc)2(dabco)] (1), [Zn2(1,4-bdc)(tmbdc)(dabco)] (2), [Zn2(tmbdc)2(dabco)] (3), [Zn2(1,4-ndc)2(dabco)] (4), [Zn2(tfbdc)2(dabco)] (5), and [Zn2(tmbdc)2(bpy)] (8) possess varying size of pores and free apertures originating from the side groups of the 1,4-bdc derivs. [Zn2(1,4-bdc)2(bpy)] (6) and [Zn2(2,6-ndc)2(bpy)] (7) have two- and 3-fold interpenetrating structures, resp. The noninterpenetrating frameworks (1-5 and 8) possess surface areas at 1450-2090 m2g-1 and H sorption capacities of 1.7-2.1% at 78 K and 1 atm. A detailed anal. of the sorption data in conjunction with structural similarities and differences concludes that porous materials with straight channels and large openings do not perform better than those with wavy channels and small openings in terms of H storage through physisorption.

      Achieving high density of adsorbed hydrogen in microporous metal organic frameworks
      Lee, Jeong Yong; Pan, Long; Kelly, Sean P.; Jagiello, Jacek; Emge, Thomas J.; Li, Jing
      Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2005), 17 (22), 2703-2706CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      An investigation of two microporous metal org. frameworks, [M3(bpdc)3bpy]·4DMF·H20 with M= Zn or Co, at low temp., revealed interesting adsorption properties. The hydrogen up-take (wt.% ) at 77 K (or 87 K) and 1 atm are 1.74 [1.32] and 1.98 [1.48] resp. for the two frameworks. The difference in H2 uptake between the two structures can be attributed to their pore vols., 0.33 and 0.38 cm3/g resp., as well as the extent of gas-solid interaction, indicated by the isosteric heat of adsorption. The d. of adsorbed H2 falls in the range of liq. H2 and suggests relatively strong sorbent-sorbate interaction in these materials with very small pores.

      Highly interpenetrated metal-organic frameworks for hydrogen storage
      Kesanli, Banu; Cui, Yong; Smith, Milton R.; Bittner, Edward W.; Brockrath, Bradley C.; Lin, Wenbin
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2005), 44 (1), 72-75CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Highly interpenetrating metal-org. frameworks were synthesized from zinc salts (i.e., Zn(ClO4)2 or ZnI2) and arom.-rich dicarboxylic acids (i.e., 6,6'-dichloro-2,2'-diethoxy-1,1'-binaphthyl-4,4'-dibenzoic acid (I) and 6,6'-dichloro-2,2'-dibenzyloxy-1,1'-binaphthyl-4,4-dibenzoic acid (II)), to form cryst. materials of general structures [Zn4(μ4-O)(I)3(DMF)2].4DMF.3MeOH.2H2O and [Zn4(μ4-O)(II)3].5DMF.5EtOH.H2O. These materials, with single-crystal x-ray diffraction patterns that suggest a fourfold three-dimensional interpenetrating networks, have hydrogen uptakes comparable to those of the best carbon nanotubes. The mechanism of hydrogen uptake seems to be favored by the proximity of arom. rings.

      Microporous Metal-Organic Frameworks Incorporating 1,4-Benzeneditetrazolate: Syntheses, Structures, and Hydrogen Storage Properties
      Dinca, Mircea; Yu, Anta F.; Long, Jeffrey R.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (27), 8904-8913CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The potential of tetrazolate-based ligands for forming metal-org. frameworks of utility in hydrogen storage is demonstrated using 1,4-benzeneditetrazolate (BDT2-) to generate robust, microporous materials. Reaction of H2BDT with MnCl2·4H2O and Mn(NO3)2·4H2O in N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) produces the two-dimensional framework solids Mn3(BDT)2Cl2(DEF)6 (1) and Mn4(BDT)3(NO3)2(DEF)6 (2), whereas reactions with hydrated salts of Mn2+, Cu2+, and Zn2+ in a mixt. of methanol and DMF afford the porous, three-dimensional framework solids Zn3(BDT)3(DMF)4(H2O)2·3.5CH3OH (3), Mn3(BDT)3(DMF)4(H2O)2·3CH3OH·2H2O·DMF (4), Mn2(BDT)Cl2(DMF)2·1.5CH3OH·H2O (5), and Cu(BDT)(DMF)·CH3OH·0.25DMF (6). The method for desolvating such compds. can dramatically influence the ensuing gas sorption properties. When subjected to a mild evacuation procedure, compds. 3-6 exhibit permanent porosity, with BET surface areas in the range 200-640 m2/g. The desolvated forms of 3-5 store between 0.82 and 1.46% H2 at 77 K and 1 atm, with enthalpies of adsorption in the range 6.0-8.8 kJ/mol, among the highest so far reported for metal-org. frameworks. The desolvated form of 6 exhibits preferential adsorption of O2 over H2 and N2, showing promise for gas sepn. and purifn. applications.

      Expanded Sodalite-Type Metal-Organic Frameworks: Increased Stability and H2 Adsorption through Ligand-Directed Catenation
      Dinca, Mircea; Dailly, Anne; Tsay, Charlene; Long, Jeffrey R.
      Inorganic Chemistry (2008), 47 (1), 11-13CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      The torsion between the central benzene ring and the outer arom. rings in 1,3,5-tri-p-(tetrazol-5-yl)phenylbenzene (H3TPB-3tz) and the absence of such strain in 2,4,6-tri-p-(tetrazol-5-yl)phenyl-s-triazine (H3TPT-3tz) are shown to allow the selective synthesis of noncatenated and catenated versions of expanded sodalite-type metal-org. frameworks. The reaction of H3TPB-3tz with CuCl2·2H2O affords the noncatenated compd. Cu3[(Cu4Cl)3(TPB-3tz)8]2·11CuCl2·8H2O·120DMF (2), while the reaction of H3TPT-3tz with MnCl2·4H2O or CuCl2·2H2O generates the catenated compds. Mn3[(Mn4Cl)3(TPT-3tz)8]2·25H2O·15CH3OH·95DMF (3) and Cu3[(Cu4Cl)3(TPT-3tz)8]2·xsolvent (4). Significantly, catenation helps to stabilize the framework toward collapse upon desolvation, leading to an increase in the surface area from 1120 to 1580 m2/g and an increase in the hydrogen storage capacity from 2.8 to 3.7 excess wt % at 77 K for 2 and 3, resp. The total hydrogen uptake in desolvated 3 reaches 4.5 wt % and 37 g/L at 80 bar and 77 K, demonstrating that control of catenation can be an important factor in the generation of hydrogen storage materials.

      Reticular Chemistry: Occurrence and Taxonomy of Nets and Grammar for the Design of Frameworks
      Ockwig, Nathan W.; Delgado-Friedrichs, Olaf; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Accounts of Chemical Research (2005), 38 (3), 176-182CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
      The structures of all 1127 three-periodic extended metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) reported in the Cambridge Structure Database were analyzed, and their underlying topol. was detd. It is remarkable that among the almost infinite no. of net topologies that are available for MOFs to adopt, only a handful of nets are actually obsd. The discovery of this inversion between expected and obsd. nets led the authors to deduce a system of classification taxonomy for interpreting and rationalizing known MOF structures, as well as those that will be made in future. The origin of this inversion is attributed to the different modes with which MOF synthesis was approached. Specifically, three levels of complexity are defined that embody rules grammar for the design of MOFs and other extended structures. This system accounts for the present proliferation of MOF structures of high symmetry nets, but more importantly, it provides the basis for designing a building block that codes for a specific structure and, indeed, only that structure.

      Metal nuclearity modulated four-, six-, and eight-connected entangled frameworks based on mono-, bi-, and trimetallic cores as nodes
      Wang, Xin-Long; Qin, Chao; Wang, En-Bo; Su, Zhong-Min
      Chemistry--A European Journal (2006), 12 (10), 2680-2691CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      To study the relation between network connectivity and metal nuclearity, the authors designed and synthesized three-dimensional (3D) entangled coordination frameworks based on different metal cores, [Zn2(bdc)2(L)2]·2H2O (1), [Zn(bdc)(L)0.5] (2), [Zn(oba)(L)0.5] (3) and [Cd3(bdc)3(L)2(H2O)2] (4) by self-assembly of d10 metal salts with the flexible long-chain ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (L), and with the rigid and nonrigid arom. dicarboxylate ligands 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) and 4,4'-oxybis(benzoate) (oba). Compd. 2 adopts a 3-fold interpenetrated α-Po-type network that is built from bimetallic cores as six-connected vertexes. The structure of 3 also consists of dinuclear units comprising a novel (3,4)-connected 3-fold interpenetrated net with complex (4.6 × 10)-(4.62 × 103) topol. when single Zn centers act as four-connected nodes (or the α-Po topol. if dinuclear units are considered as six-connected nodes). 4, Derived from a cross-linked 5-fold interpenetrated diamond-like substructure, is an unusual example of a self-penetrating coordination framework displaying an unprecedented eight-connected 42068 topol. with trinuclear Cd clusters as eight-connected nodes which, to the authors' knowledge, not only defines a new topol. for eight-connected coordination networks, but also represents the highest connected topol. presently known for self-penetrating systems. Detailed structural comparison of these complexes indicates that the increase in metal nuclearity induces the progressive increase in the connectivities of the ultimate nets: i.e., the metal nuclearity plays a significant role in tuning the connectivity of a specific network. The thermal and luminescent properties of these compds. are discussed.

      11
      Single-crystal structure validation with the program PLATON
      Spek, A. L.
      Journal of Applied Crystallography (2003), 36 (1), 7-13CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:0021-8898. (Blackwell Munksgaard)
      The results of a single-crystal structure detn. when in CIF format can now be validated routinely by automatic procedures. In this way, many errors in published papers can be avoided. The validation software generates a set of ALERTS detailing issues to be addressed by the experimenter, author, referee and publication journal. Validation was pioneered by the IUCr journal Acta Crystallographica Section C and is currently std. procedure for structures submitted for publication in all IUCr journals. The implementation of validation procedures by other journals is in progress. This paper describes the concepts of validation and the classes of checks that are carried out by the program PLATON as part of the IUCr check CIF facility. PLATON validation can be run at any stage of the structure refinement, independent of the structure detn. package used, and is recommended for use as a routine tool during or at least at the completion of every structure detn. Two examples are discussed where proper validation procedures could have avoided the publication of incorrect structures that had serious consequences for the chem. involved.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXltlChtw%253D%253D&md5=0a85de2407551632bb287508534904e2

      Hydrogen storage in the giant-pore metal-organic frameworks MIL-100 and MIL-101
      Latroche, Michel; Suble, Suzy; Serre, Christian; Mellot-Draznieks, Caroline; Llewellyn, Philip L.; Lee, Jin-Ho; Chang, Jong-San; Jhung, Sung Hwa; Ferey, Gerard

Satn. pressures vary between 25 and 80 bar across the series, with MOF-177 showing the highest uptake on a gravimetric basis (7.5 wt %) and IRMOF-20 showing the highest uptake on a volumetric basis at 34 g/L.       Impact of Preparation and Handling on the Hydrogen Storage Properties of Zn4O(1,4-benzenedicarboxylate)3 (MOF-5)
      Kaye, Steven S.; Dailly, Anne; Yaghi, Omar M.; Long, Jeffrey R.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (46), 14176-14177CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The prototypical metal-org. framework Zn4O(BDC)3 (MOF-5, BDC2- = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) decomps. gradually in humid air to form a nonporous solid. Recognizing this, improved procedures for its synthesis and handling were developed, leading to significant increases in N2 and H2 gas adsorption capacities. Nitrogen adsorption isotherms measured at 77 K reveal an enhanced max. N2 uptake of 44.5 mmol/g and a BET surface area of 3800 m2/g, compared to the 35.8 mmol/g and 3100 m2/g obtained for a sample prepd. using previous methods. High-pressure H2 adsorption isotherms show improvements from 5.0 to 7.1 excess wt. % at 77 K and 40 bar. The total H2 uptake was further obsd. to climb to 11.5% at 170 bar, corresponding to a volumetric storage d. of 77 g/L. Thus, the air-free compd. exhibits the highest gravimetric and volumetric H2 uptake capacities yet demonstrated for a cryogenic hydrogen storage material. Also, no loss of capacity was apparent during 24 complete adsorption-desorption cycles, while kinetics measurements showed a loading time of 2 min with application of just 45 bar of pressure.

      Strategies for hydrogen storage in metal-organic frameworks
      Rowsell, Jesse L. C.; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2005), 44 (30), 4670-4679CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A review. Increased attention is being focused on metal-org. frameworks as candidates for hydrogen storage materials. This is a result of their many favorable attributes, such as high porosity, reproducible and facile syntheses, amenability to scale-up, and chem. modification for targeting desired properties. A discussion of several strategies aimed at improving hydrogen uptake in these materials is presented. These strategies include the optimization of pore size and adsorption energy by linker modification, impregnation, catenation, and the inclusion of open metal sites and lighter metals.

      Chemical Activation of Single-Walled Carbon Nanotubes for Hydrogen Adsorption
      Smith, Milton R., Jr.; Bittner, Edward W.; Shi, Wei; Johnson, J. Karl; Bockrath, Bradley C.
      Journal of Physical Chemistry B (2003), 107 (16), 3752-3760CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1520-6106. (American Chemical Society)
      Adsorption isotherms for hydrogen on single-walled nanotubes (SWNTs) subjected to various types of pretreatment have been measured by a tapered-element oscillating mass analyzer. Isotherms at room temp. over a range of pressures up to 48 bar have been measured. We demonstrate that activation of the SWNT samples by mild oxidn. in CO2, followed by heat treatment in an inert atm., increases the hydrogen adsorption capacity of the SWNT samples by about a factor of 3 at 48 bar. Computer simulations have been performed to model the adsorption isotherms. Bundles of homogeneous (all the same diam.) and heterogeneous (composed of a no. of different diams.) nanotubes have been considered. Isotherms computed using a std. graphitic potential for the nanotubes give remarkably good agreement with the exptl. measured isotherms before activation with CO2. The effect of activation is modeled by independently increasing the nanotube spacing and the solid-fluid interaction potential. We find that nanotube spacing alone cannot account for the measured increase in adsorption capacity. Increasing the interaction potential gives isotherms that are qual. different from expts., while a combination of increased nanotube spacing and increased solid-fluid potential gives rough agreement with expts.

        Role of Solvent-Host Interactions That Lead to Very Large Swelling of Hybrid Frameworks
        Serre, C.; Mellot-Draznieks, C.; Surble, S.; Audebrand, N.; Filinchuk, Y.; Ferey, G.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2007), 315 (5820), 1828-1831CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        An unusually large expansion upon solvent adsorption occurs without apparent bond breaking in the network of a series of isoreticular chromium(III) or iron(III) dicarboxylates labeled MIL-88A to D [dicarbox = fumarate (88A); terephthalate (1,4-BDC) (88B); 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate (2,6-NDC) (88C); and 4-4'-biphenyldicarboxylate (4-4'-BPDC) (88D)]. This reversible "breathing" motion was analyzed in terms of cell dimensions (extent of breathing), movements within the framework (mechanism of transformation), and the interactions between the guests and the skeleton. In situ techniques show that these flexible solids are highly selective absorbents and that this selectivity is strongly dependent on the nature of the org. linker.

        1c
        Framework Engineering by Anions and Porous Functionalities of Cu(II)/4,4'-bpy Coordination Polymers
        Noro, Shin-ichiro; Kitaura, Ryo; Kondo, Mitsuru; Kitagawa, Susumu; Ishii, Tomohiko; Matsuzaka, Hiroyuki; Yamashita, Masahiro
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2002), 124 (11), 2568-2583CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A combination of framework-builder Cu2+ and 4,4'-bipyridine (4,4'-bpy) ligand) and framework-regulator (AF6 type anions; A = Si, Ge, and P) provides novel porous coordination polymers. The highly porous coordination polymers {[Cu(AF6)(4,4'-bpy)2]·8H2O}n (A = Si (1a·8H2O), Ge (2a·8H2O)) afford robust 3-dimensional (3-D), microporous networks (3-dimensional Regular Grid) by using AF62- anions. The channel size of these complexes is ∼8 × 8 Å2 along the c-axis and 6 × 2 Å2 along the a- or b-axes. When compds. 1a·8H2O or 2a·8H2O were immersed in H2O, a conversion of 3-dimensional networks (1a·8H2O or 2a·8H2O) to interpenetrated networks {[Cu(4,4'-bpy)2(H2O)2]·AF6}n (A = Si (1b) and Ge (2b)) (2-dimensional Interpenetration) took place. This 2-dimensional interpenetrated network 1b shows unique dynamic anion-exchange properties, which accompany drastic structural conversions. When a PF6- monoanion instead of AF62- dianions was used as the framework-regulator with another co-counteranion (coexistent anions), porous coordination polymers with various types of frameworks, {[Cu2(4,4'-bpy)5(H2O)4]·anions·2H2O·4EtOH}n (anions = 4PF6- (3·2H2O·4EtOH), 2PF6- + 2ClO4- (4·2H2O·4EtOH)) (2-dimensional Double-Layer), {[Cu2(PF6)(NO3)(4,4'-bpy)4]·2PF6·2H2O}n (5·2PF6·2H2O) (3-dimensional Undulated Grid), {[Cu(PF6)(4,4'-bpy)2(MeCN)]·PF6·2MeCN}n (6·2MeCN) (2-dimensional Grid), and {[Cu(4,4'-bpy)2(H2O)2]·PF6·BF4}n (7) (2-dimensional Grid), were obtained, where the three modes of PF6- anions are obsd. 5·2PF6·2H2O has rare PF6- bridges. The PF6- and NO3- monoanions alternately link to the Cu(II) centers in the undulated 2-dimensional sheets of [Cu(4,4'-bpy)2]n to form a 3-dimensional porous network. The free PF6- anions are included in the channels. 6·2MeCN affords both free and terminal-bridged PF6- anions. 3·2H2O·4EtOH, 4·2H2O·4EtOH, and 7 bear free PF6- anions. All of the anions in 3·2H2O·4EtOH and 4·2H2O·4EtOH are freely located in the channels constructed from a host network. Interestingly, these Cu(II) frameworks are rationally controlled by counteranions and selectively converted to other frameworks.

        1d
        Hysteretic Adsorption and Desorption of Hydrogen by Nanoporous Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Zhao, Xuebo; Xiao, Bo; Fletcher, Ashleigh J.; Thomas, K. Mark; Bradshaw, Darren; Rosseinsky, Matthew J.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2004), 306 (5698), 1012-1015CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        Adsorption and desorption of hydrogen from nanoporous materials, such as activated C, is usually fully reversible. The authors prepd. nanoporous metal-org. framework materials with flexible linkers in which the pore openings, as characterized in the static structures, appear to be too small to allow H2 to pass. The authors observe hysteresis in their adsorption and desorption kinetics above the supercrit. temp. of H2 that reflects the dynamical opening of the windows between pores. This behavior would allow H2 to be adsorbed at high pressures but stored at lower pressures.

        Chiral porous coordination networks: rational design and applications in enantioselective processes
        Kesanli, Banu; Lin, Wenbin
        Coordination Chemistry Reviews (2003), 246 (1-2), 305-326CODEN: CCHRAM; ISSN:0010-8545. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
        A review is presented which provides a short discussion of recent progress in the synthesis and characterization of homochiral metal-org. coordination networks (MOCNs) and their applications in the areas of asym. catalysis and chiral sepns. Although chiral MOCNs can be constructed from achiral components, the resulting bulk solids tend to be racemic and are thus not useful for enantioselective processes. A couple of examples of homochiral solids built from achiral bridging ligands are presented along with more prevalent homochiral MOCNs built from chiral bridging ligands that are categorized based on their network dimensionality. Preliminary applications of these homochiral solids in asym. catalysis and chiral sepns. are also presented.

        A homochiral metal-organic porous material for enantioselective separation and catalysis
        Seo, Jung Soo; Whang, Dongmok; Lee, Hyoyoung; Jun, Sung Im; Oh, Jinho; Jeon, Young Jin; Kim, Kimoon
        Nature (London) (2000), 404 (6781), 982-986CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A homochiral metal-org. porous material with a carboxylic group at one end and a pyridyl group at the other forming oxo-bridged trinuclear metal carboxylate units in a three-dimensional framework was prepd., that allows enantioselective inclusion of metal complexes in its pores and catalyzes transesterification reactions in an enantioselective manner. The enantiopure chiral building block was prepd. from D-tartaric acid and 4-aminopyridine; then reaction with Zn2+ produced a homochiral open-framework solid, D-POST-1. The enantiomorphic L-POST-1 was obtained from the enantiomer of the building block and Zn2+ under the same conditions. The pyridyl groups in POST-1 can be converted to N-methylpyridinium without any changes of the network structure; the anion can be reversibly exchanged with other anions, e.g., PF6-, I3-, p-toluenesulfonate, etc. The pore size of POST-1 materials is modulated by N-alkylation and is dependent on alkyl chain length. The pyridyl groups are responsible for the catalytic activity of the oxo-bridged trinuclear metal complexes, in e.g., transesterification of 2,4-dinitrophenyl acetate (NPA) with ethanol, which produced Et acetate in 77% yield, only in the presence of POST-1. Transesterification with bulkier alcs. occurs more slowly or not at all, suggesting that catalysis occurs mainly in the POST-1 channels. The catalytic activity of D- and L-POST-1 is enantioselective as obsd. in the transesterification of NPA with 1-phenyl-2-propanol, which produces the corresponding esters with about 88% enantiomeric excess in favor of the resp. enantiomer.

        Microporous Metal Organic Materials: Promising Candidates as Sorbents for Hydrogen Storage
        Pan, Long; Sander, Michelle B.; Huang, Xiaoying; Li, Jing; Smith, Milton; Bittner, Edward; Bockrath, Bradley; Johnson, J. Karl
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2004), 126 (5), 1308-1309CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Although extensive efforts have been made to improve H storage techniques, there is no viable storage technol. capable of meeting the DOE cost and performance targets. New materials with significantly improved H adsorption capability are needed. Microporous metal coordination materials (MMOMs) are promising sorbents for H adsorption. These materials possess phys. characteristics similar to those of single-walled C nanotubes and they also have a no. of advantages. A novel MMOM structure and its room-temp. H adsorption properties are presented.

        Metal-org. framework-5 (MOF-5) Zn4O(BDC)3 (BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) with a cubic three-dimensional extended porous structure adsorbed hydrogen up to 4.5 wt.% (17.2 hydrogen mols. per formula unit) at 78 K and 1.0 wt.% at room temp. and pressure of 20 bar.         Synthesis, X-ray crystal structures, and gas sorption properties of pillared square grid nets based on paddle-wheel motifs: Implications for hydrogen storage in porous materials
        Chun, Hyungphil; Dybtsev, Danil N.; Kim, Hyunuk; Kim, Kimoon
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2005), 11 (12), 3521-3529CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A systematic modulation of org. ligands connecting dinuclear paddle-wheel motifs leads to isomorphous metal-org. porous materials that have a three-dimensional connectivity and interconnected pores. Arom. dicarboxylates such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (1,4-bdc), tetramethylterephthalate (tmbdc), 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate (1,4-ndc), tetrafluoroterephthalate (tfbdc), or 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate (2,6-ndc) are linear linkers that form two-dimensional layers, and diamine ligands, 4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (dabco) or 4,4'-dipyridyl (bpy), coordinate at both sides of Zn2 paddle-wheel units to bridge the layers vertically. The resulting open frameworks [Zn2(1,4-bdc)2(dabco)] (1), [Zn2(1,4-bdc)(tmbdc)(dabco)] (2), [Zn2(tmbdc)2(dabco)] (3), [Zn2(1,4-ndc)2(dabco)] (4), [Zn2(tfbdc)2(dabco)] (5), and [Zn2(tmbdc)2(bpy)] (8) possess varying size of pores and free apertures originating from the side groups of the 1,4-bdc derivs. [Zn2(1,4-bdc)2(bpy)] (6) and [Zn2(2,6-ndc)2(bpy)] (7) have two- and 3-fold interpenetrating structures, resp. The noninterpenetrating frameworks (1-5 and 8) possess surface areas at 1450-2090 m2g-1 and H sorption capacities of 1.7-2.1% at 78 K and 1 atm. A detailed anal. of the sorption data in conjunction with structural similarities and differences concludes that porous materials with straight channels and large openings do not perform better than those with wavy channels and small openings in terms of H storage through physisorption.

        Achieving high density of adsorbed hydrogen in microporous metal organic frameworks
        Lee, Jeong Yong; Pan, Long; Kelly, Sean P.; Jagiello, Jacek; Emge, Thomas J.; Li, Jing
        Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2005), 17 (22), 2703-2706CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        An investigation of two microporous metal org. frameworks, [M3(bpdc)3bpy]·4DMF·H20 with M= Zn or Co, at low temp., revealed interesting adsorption properties. The hydrogen up-take (wt.% ) at 77 K (or 87 K) and 1 atm are 1.74 [1.32] and 1.98 [1.48] resp. for the two frameworks. The difference in H2 uptake between the two structures can be attributed to their pore vols., 0.33 and 0.38 cm3/g resp., as well as the extent of gas-solid interaction, indicated by the isosteric heat of adsorption. The d. of adsorbed H2 falls in the range of liq. H2 and suggests relatively strong sorbent-sorbate interaction in these materials with very small pores.

        Highly interpenetrated metal-organic frameworks for hydrogen storage

        Microporous Metal-Organic Frameworks Incorporating 1,4-Benzeneditetrazolate: Syntheses, Structures, and Hydrogen Storage Properties
        Dinca, Mircea; Yu, Anta F.; Long, Jeffrey R.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (27), 8904-8913CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The potential of tetrazolate-based ligands for forming metal-org. frameworks of utility in hydrogen storage is demonstrated using 1,4-benzeneditetrazolate (BDT2-) to generate robust, microporous materials. Reaction of H2BDT with MnCl2·4H2O and Mn(NO3)2·4H2O in N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) produces the two-dimensional framework solids Mn3(BDT)2Cl2(DEF)6 (1) and Mn4(BDT)3(NO3)2(DEF)6 (2), whereas reactions with hydrated salts of Mn2+, Cu2+, and Zn2+ in a mixt. of methanol and DMF afford the porous, three-dimensional framework solids Zn3(BDT)3(DMF)4(H2O)2·3.5CH3OH (3), Mn3(BDT)3(DMF)4(H2O)2·3CH3OH·2H2O·DMF (4), Mn2(BDT)Cl2(DMF)2·1.5CH3OH·H2O (5), and Cu(BDT)(DMF)·CH3OH·0.25DMF (6). The method for desolvating such compds. can dramatically influence the ensuing gas sorption properties. When subjected to a mild evacuation procedure, compds. 3-6 exhibit permanent porosity, with BET surface areas in the range 200-640 m2/g. The desolvated forms of 3-5 store between 0.82 and 1.46% H2 at 77 K and 1 atm, with enthalpies of adsorption in the range 6.0-8.8 kJ/mol, among the highest so far reported for metal-org. frameworks. The desolvated form of 6 exhibits preferential adsorption of O2 over H2 and N2, showing promise for gas sepn. and purifn. applications.

        Expanded Sodalite-Type Metal-Organic Frameworks: Increased Stability and H2 Adsorption through Ligand-Directed Catenation
        Dinca, Mircea; Dailly, Anne; Tsay, Charlene; Long, Jeffrey R.
        Inorganic Chemistry (2008), 47 (1), 11-13CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        The torsion between the central benzene ring and the outer arom. rings in 1,3,5-tri-p-(tetrazol-5-yl)phenylbenzene (H3TPB-3tz) and the absence of such strain in 2,4,6-tri-p-(tetrazol-5-yl)phenyl-s-triazine (H3TPT-3tz) are shown to allow the selective synthesis of noncatenated and catenated versions of expanded sodalite-type metal-org. frameworks. The reaction of H3TPB-3tz with CuCl2·2H2O affords the noncatenated compd. Cu3[(Cu4Cl)3(TPB-3tz)8]2·11CuCl2·8H2O·120DMF (2), while the reaction of H3TPT-3tz with MnCl2·4H2O or CuCl2·2H2O generates the catenated compds. Mn3[(Mn4Cl)3(TPT-3tz)8]2·25H2O·15CH3OH·95DMF (3) and Cu3[(Cu4Cl)3(TPT-3tz)8]2·xsolvent (4). Significantly, catenation helps to stabilize the framework toward collapse upon desolvation, leading to an increase in the surface area from 1120 to 1580 m2/g and an increase in the hydrogen storage capacity from 2.8 to 3.7 excess wt % at 77 K for 2 and 3, resp. The total hydrogen uptake in desolvated 3 reaches 4.5 wt % and 37 g/L at 80 bar and 77 K, demonstrating that control of catenation can be an important factor in the generation of hydrogen storage materials.

        Reticular Chemistry: Occurrence and Taxonomy of Nets and Grammar for the Design of Frameworks
        Ockwig, Nathan W.; Delgado-Friedrichs, Olaf; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2005), 38 (3), 176-182CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        The structures of all 1127 three-periodic extended metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) reported in the Cambridge Structure Database were analyzed, and their underlying topol. was detd. It is remarkable that among the almost infinite no. of net topologies that are available for MOFs to adopt, only a handful of nets are actually obsd. The discovery of this inversion between expected and obsd. nets led the authors to deduce a system of classification taxonomy for interpreting and rationalizing known MOF structures, as well as those that will be made in future. The origin of this inversion is attributed to the different modes with which MOF synthesis was approached. Specifically, three levels of complexity are defined that embody rules grammar for the design of MOFs and other extended structures. This system accounts for the present proliferation of MOF structures of high symmetry nets, but more importantly, it provides the basis for designing a building block that codes for a specific structure and, indeed, only that structure.

        Chemistry--A European Journal (2006), 12 (10), 2680-2691CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        To study the relation between network connectivity and metal nuclearity, the authors designed and synthesized three-dimensional (3D) entangled coordination frameworks based on different metal cores, [Zn2(bdc)2(L)2]·2H2O (1), [Zn(bdc)(L)0.5] (2), [Zn(oba)(L)0.5] (3) and [Cd3(bdc)3(L)2(H2O)2] (4) by self-assembly of d10 metal salts with the flexible long-chain ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (L), and with the rigid and nonrigid arom. dicarboxylate ligands 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) and 4,4'-oxybis(benzoate) (oba). Compd. 1 exhibits a 3-fold interpenetrated diamondoid array typically based on a tetrahedral 2nd building unit (SBU) at a single Zn center. Compd. 2 adopts a 3-fold interpenetrated α-Po-type network that is built from bimetallic cores as six-connected vertexes. The structure of 3 also consists of dinuclear units comprising a novel (3,4)-connected 3-fold interpenetrated net with complex (4.6 × 10)-(4.62 × 103) topol. when single Zn centers act as four-connected nodes (or the α-Po topol. if dinuclear units are considered as six-connected nodes). 4, Derived from a cross-linked 5-fold interpenetrated diamond-like substructure, is an unusual example of a self-penetrating coordination framework displaying an unprecedented eight-connected 42068 topol. with trinuclear Cd clusters as eight-connected nodes which, to the authors' knowledge, not only defines a new topol. for eight-connected coordination networks, but also represents the highest connected topol. presently known for self-penetrating systems. Detailed structural comparison of these complexes indicates that the increase in metal nuclearity induces the progressive increase in the connectivities of the ultimate nets: i.e., the metal nuclearity plays a significant role in tuning the connectivity of a specific network. The thermal and luminescent properties of these compds. are discussed.

        Synthesis of Inorganic Fullerene-Like Molecules
        Bai, Junfeng; Virovets, Alexander V.; Scheer, Manfred
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2003), 300 (5620), 781-783CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        The reaction of [Cp*Fe(η5-P5)] with Cu(I)Cl in solvent mixts. of CH2Cl2/CH3CN leads to the formation of entirely inorg. fullerene-like mols. of the formula [{Cp*Fe(η5:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1-P5)}12{CuCl}10{Cu2Cl3}5{Cu(CH3CN)2}5] (1) possessing 90 inorg. core atoms. This compd. represents a structural motif similar to that of C60: cyclo-P5 rings of [Cp*Fe(η5-P5)] mols. are surrounded by six-membered P4Cu2 rings that result from the coordination of each of the phosphorus lone pairs to CuCl metal centers, which are further coordinated by P atoms of other cyclo-P5 rings. Thus, five- and six-membered rings alternate in a manner comparable to that obsd. in the fullerene mols. The so-formed half shells are joined by [Cu2Cl3]- as well as by [Cu(CH3CN)2]+ units. The spherical body has an inside diam. of 1.25 nm and an outside diam. of 2.13 nm, which is about three times as large as that of C60.

        Two novel two-dimensional (2D) and one three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymers, [Ni(HTTG)(H2O)2]n (1), [Co(HTTG)(H2O)2]n (2), and [Cd(HTTG)]n (3), were hydrothermally synthesized by self-assembly of an unexplored tripodal ligand H3TTG (N,N',N''-1,3,5-triazine-2,4,6-triyltris-glycine) and corresponding metal salts. The isostructural complexes 1 and 2 possess 2-dimensional frameworks with M(H2O)2(CO2)2 chains bridged by the ligands, and the resulting 3-dimensional networks were extended through R22(8) H bonds between the non-deprotonated carboxylate groups and the triazine rings as well as π···π interactions between the triazine rings. Complex 3 shows a 3-dimensional interpenetrating compact network with inorg. Cd2O2 chains interconnected by the flexible org. ligands. Topol. anal. indicates that in all three complexes the tripodal ligand acts as a four-connected square-planar node, linking four-connected square-planar or tetrahedral-connected metal centers to form interesting two-dimensional (2D) (4,4) (in 1 and 2) and three-dimensional (3D) 2-fold interpenetrating PtS topologies (in 3), resp. Both 1 and 2 exhibit ferromagnetic interactions within the chains bridged by the syn-anti carboxylate groups and the H2O mols. alternately, and complex 3 displays strong photoluminescent properties at 413 nm due to the coordination of the ligands with the metal centers.

        Single-crystal structure validation with the program PLATON
        Spek, A. L.
        Journal of Applied Crystallography (2003), 36 (1), 7-13CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:0021-8898. (Blackwell Munksgaard)
        The results of a single-crystal structure detn. when in CIF format can now be validated routinely by automatic procedures. In this way, many errors in published papers can be avoided. The validation software generates a set of ALERTS detailing issues to be addressed by the experimenter, author, referee and publication journal. Validation was pioneered by the IUCr journal Acta Crystallographica Section C and is currently std. procedure for structures submitted for publication in all IUCr journals. The implementation of validation procedures by other journals is in progress. This paper describes the concepts of validation and the classes of checks that are carried out by the program PLATON as part of the IUCr check CIF facility. PLATON validation can be run at any stage of the structure refinement, independent of the structure detn. package used, and is recommended for use as a routine tool during or at least at the completion of every structure detn. Two examples are discussed where proper validation procedures could have avoided the publication of incorrect structures that had serious consequences for the chem. involved.

However, MIL-101 has low hydrogen uptake at room temp. The small pores of MIL-101 play a major role in H absorption and the large empty space generated by the large cages leads to very large pores that are not as effective for H storage. In the architecture of this porous solid each intersection of the cages is occupied by a super-tetrahedron formed by trimers of Cr octahedra assembled with benzene-1,4-dicarboxylate ligands.

        Impact of Preparation and Handling on the Hydrogen Storage Properties of Zn4O(1,4-benzenedicarboxylate)3 (MOF-5)
        Kaye, Steven S.; Dailly, Anne; Yaghi, Omar M.; Long, Jeffrey R.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (46), 14176-14177CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The prototypical metal-org. framework Zn4O(BDC)3 (MOF-5, BDC2- = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) decomps. gradually in humid air to form a nonporous solid. Nitrogen adsorption isotherms measured at 77 K reveal an enhanced max. N2 uptake of 44.5 mmol/g and a BET surface area of 3800 m2/g, compared to the 35.8 mmol/g and 3100 m2/g obtained for a sample prepd. using previous methods. High-pressure H2 adsorption isotherms show improvements from 5.0 to 7.1 excess wt. % at 77 K and 40 bar. The total H2 uptake was further obsd. to climb to 11.5% at 170 bar, corresponding to a volumetric storage d. of 77 g/L. Thus, the air-free compd. exhibits the highest gravimetric and volumetric H2 uptake capacities yet demonstrated for a cryogenic hydrogen storage material. Also, no loss of capacity was apparent during 24 complete adsorption-desorption cycles, while kinetics measurements showed a loading time of 2 min with application of just 45 bar of pressure.

        Chemical Activation of Single-Walled Carbon Nanotubes for Hydrogen Adsorption
        Smith, Milton R., Jr.; Bittner, Edward W.; Shi, Wei; Johnson, J. Karl; Bockrath, Bradley C.
        Journal of Physical Chemistry B (2003), 107 (16), 3752-3760CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1520-6106. (American Chemical Society)
        Adsorption isotherms for hydrogen on single-walled nanotubes (SWNTs) subjected to various types of pretreatment have been measured by a tapered-element oscillating mass analyzer. Isotherms at room temp. over a range of pressures up to 48 bar have been measured. We demonstrate that activation of the SWNT samples by mild oxidn. in CO2, followed by heat treatment in an inert atm., increases the hydrogen adsorption capacity of the SWNT samples by about a factor of 3 at 48 bar. Computer simulations have been performed to model the adsorption isotherms. Bundles of homogeneous (all the same diam.) and heterogeneous (composed of a no. of different diams.) nanotubes have been considered. Isotherms computed using a std. graphitic potential for the nanotubes give remarkably good agreement with the exptl. measured isotherms before activation with CO2. The effect of activation is modeled by independently increasing the nanotube spacing and the solid-fluid interaction potential. We find that nanotube spacing alone cannot account for the measured increase in adsorption capacity. Increasing the interaction potential gives isotherms that are qual. different from expts., while a combination of increased nanotube spacing and increased solid-fluid potential gives rough agreement with expts.

        2D Molecular Square Grid with Strong Blue Fluorescent Emission: A Complex of Norfloxacin with Zinc(II)
        Chen, Zhen-Feng; Xiong, Ren-Gen; Zhang, Jing; Chen, Xue-Tai; Xue, Zi-Ling; You, Xiao-Zeng
        Inorganic Chemistry (2001), 40 (16), 4075-4077CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        The hydrothermal reactions of norfloxacin (H-Norf) with Zn(OH)2 and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, resp., afford two different products, Zn(Norf)2·4H2O (1) and Zn(H-Norf)2.(NO3)2·2H2O(2). 1 Represents an unprecedented neutral metal-based mol. square grid with strong blue fluorescent emission. 1 Is monoclinic, space group P21/c, Z = 2, R1 = 0.0456, wR2 = 0.1221. 2 Is triclinic, space group P‾1, Z = 1, R1 = 0.0578, wR2 = 0.1734. 2 Has a distorted octahedral structure with 2 coordinated H2O mols.

        Synthesis, Structure, and Fluorescence of the Novel Cadmium(II)-Trimesate Coordination Polymers with Different Coordination Architectures
        Dai, Jing-Cao; Wu, Xin-Tao; Fu, Zhi-Yong; Cui, Chuan-Peng; Hu, Sheng-Min; Du, Wen-Xin; Wu, Li-Ming; Zhang, Han-Hui; Sun, Rui-Qing
        Inorganic Chemistry (2002), 41 (6), 1391-1396CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Three novel complexes, Cd3tma2·13H2O (1), Cd3tma2·dabco·2H2O (2), and Cd3Htma3·8H2O (3) (tma = trimesate, dabco = 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane), of Cd(II)-trimesate coordination polymers were obtained from hydrothermal reaction. 1 (C18H32O25Cd3) crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c [a = 18.985(2) Å, b 7.3872(6), c 20.432(2) Å, β 97.1660(10)°, and Z = 4]. 2 (C24H22N2O14Cd3) crystallizes in the monoclinic P2(1)/c space group [a = 10.1323(2) Å, b 19.5669(5), c 13.15880(10) Å, β 108.9810(10)°, and Z = 4]. 3 (C27H28O26Cd3) belongs to the trigonal P31c space group [a = 15.7547(3) Å, b 15.7547(3), c 7.93160(10) Å, and Z = 2]. 1 (C18H32O25Cd3) crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c [a = 18.985(2), b 7.3872(6), c 20.432(2) Å, β 97.1660(10)°, and Z = 4]; 2 (C24H22N2O14Cd3) crystallizes in the monoclinic P2(1)/c space group [a = 10.1323(2), b 19.5669(5), c 13.15880(10) Å, β 108.9810(10)°, and Z = 4]; 3 (C27H28O26Cd3) belongs to the trigonal P31c space group [a = 15.7547(3), b 15.7547(3), c 7.93160(10) Å, and Z = 2]. The Cd(II) centers in the three complexes are bridged by tma ligands in the coordination fashion of unidentate, bridging unidentate, bidentate, chelating bis-bidentate, chelating/bridging bis-bidentate, or chelating/bridging bidentate to form the T-shaped mol. bilayer motif for 1, chicken-wire-like motif for 2, and honeycomb-like porous structure for 3, resp., in which the T-shaped mol. bilayer motif and chicken-wire-like motif are further interlinked in interdigitating or alternating fashion to construct the different coordination architectures. These three complexes exhibit strong fluorescent emission bands at 355 nm (λex = 220 nm) for 1, 437 nm (λex = 365 nm) for 2, and 353 nm (λex = 218 nm) for 3 in the solid state at room temp.

        Syntheses, Structures, and Photoluminescence of a Novel Class of d10 Metal Complexes Constructed from Pyridine-3,4-dicarboxylic Acid with Different Coordination Architectures
        Wang, Xinlong; Qin, Chao; Wang, Enbo; Li, Yangguang; Hao, Na; Hu, Changwen; Xu, Lin
        Inorganic Chemistry (2004), 43 (6), 1850-1856CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Two novel d10 metal coordination polymers [Zn(PDB)]n (1) and [Cd3(PDB)2(OH)2(H2O)2]n (2) (H2PDB = pyridine-3,4-dicarboxylic acid) were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions and characterized by elemental anal., IR, TGA, and single-crystal x-ray diffraction. Crystal data for 1: C7H3NO4Zn, orthorhombic space group Pna21, a 8.423(17), b 6.574(13), c 12.899(3) Å, Z = 4. Crystal data for 2: C14H12N2O12Cd3, monoclinic space group C2/c, a 20.130(4), b 6.692(13), c 13.081(3) Å, β 102.78(3)°, Z = 4. Both compds. exhibit novel three-dimensional frameworks. Compd. 1 not only possesses a 1-dimensional rectangular channel but also contains infinite double-stranded helical chains. Compd. 2 has two different types of channels, one being built up from pyridine rings and {CdO5N} and {CdO6} building units and the other being constructed from pyridine rings and {CdO5N} building units. Also, both compds. show strong photoluminescence properties at room temp.

        Structure, Luminescence, and Adsorption Properties of Two Chiral Microporous Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Fang, Qianrong; Zhu, Guangshan; Xue, Ming; Sun, Jinyu; Sun, Fuxing; Qiu, Shilun
        Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (9), 3582-3587CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Two 3-dimensional chiral multifunctional microporous MOFs, Zn3(BTC)2(DMF)3(H2O)·(DMF)(H2O) (1) and Cd4(BTC)3(DMF)2(H2O)2·6(H2O) (2) (H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid), were synthesized in the presence of org. bases tributylamine (TBA) and NEt3 (TEA), resp. 1 (C30H38N4O18Zn3) crystallizes in the tetragonal space group P41212 (a 13.6929(19), c 50.664(10) Å, and Z = 8). 2 (C33H39N2O28Cd4) crystallizes in the tetragonal space group P4322 (a 10.3503(4), c 52.557(3) Å, and Z = 4). X-ray crystallog. reveals that 1 consists of a 3-dimensional open framework with the (63)4(62·82·102)(6·482)2 topol., but 2 exhibits a 3-dimensional open network with the (42·5)2(4·45·106·87·482) topol. The solid-state excitation-emission spectra show that the strongest excitation peaks for 1 and 2 are at 341 and 319 nm, and their emission spectra mainly show strong peaks at 410 and 405 nm, resp. The amts. adsorbed of 1 (2) are 169 mg/g (126 mg/g) for H2O, 137 mg/g (102 mg/g) for EtOH, and 133 mg/g (99 mg/g) for MeOH, which are equiv. to the adsorption of ∼62(34) H2O, 20(11) EtOH, and 28(16) MeOH per unit cell, resp.

        (c) Guo, X. D.; Zhu, G. S.; Fang, Q. R.; Xue, M.; Tian, G.; Sun, J. Y.; Li, X. T.; Qiu, S. L. Inorg. Chem. 2005, 44, 3850

        18c
        Synthesis, Structure and Luminescent Properties of Rare Earth Coordination Polymers Constructed from Paddle-Wheel Building Blocks
        Guo, Xiaodan; Zhu, Guangshan; Fang, Qianrong; Xue, Ming; Tian, Ge; Sun, Jinyu; Li, Xiaotian; Qiu, Shilun
        Inorganic Chemistry (2005), 44 (11), 3850-3855CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Three-dimensional (3D) novel coordination polymers M(bpdc)1.5(H2O)·0.5DMF (M = Tb (1), Ho (2), Er (3), or Y (4)) were synthesized by reaction of the rare earth ions (M3+) with 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid (H2bpdc) in a mixed soln. of DMF and EtOH. They possess the same 3-dimensional architectures and crystallize in monoclinic space group C2/c. Two seven-coordinated metal centers and four dimonodentate bpdc groups construct a paddle-wheel building block. These building blocks connect with two carboxyl groups to lead to a 1-dimensional inorg. chain, ---M-O-C-O-M..., along the [001] direction. The inorg. chains are linked with two biphenyl groups to form 25.15 Å × 17.09 Å rhombic channels along the c axis without interpenetration. These complexes exhibit strong fluorescence in the visible region, and complex 3 shows Er3+ characteristic emission at 1450-1650 nm at room temp. These complexes could be anticipated as potential fluorescent probes and an IR-emitter, resp.
